title: Judgment on Babylon
shortSummary: Jeremiah 50 prophesies the coming destruction of Babylon as a divine judgment for its pride, idolatry, and oppression of Israel and Judah. The chapter foretells the gathering of nations from the north to overthrow Babylon, the restoration of God's people, and the ultimate desolation of the once mighty empire. This chapter emphasizes God's sovereignty and justice in punishing the oppressors and redeeming His covenant people.
timeline: c. 6th century BC - Babylonian Exile and Prophecies of Judgment

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet through whom God delivers the message of judgment against Babylon and hope for Israel and Judah.

keyCharacters.name: King of Babylon
keyCharacters.description: The ruler of Babylon who symbolizes the pride and oppression that will be punished by God.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadrezzar
keyCharacters.description: The Babylonian king noted for his role in oppressing Israel and Judah, mentioned as having 'broken their bones.'

keyCharacters.name: Children of Israel and Judah
keyCharacters.description: God’s covenant people who will be restored and seek the Lord after Babylon’s judgment.

definitions.definition: The people of Babylon, often used interchangeably with Babylonians, known for their idolatry and opposition to Israel.
A Babylonian deity whose image is prophesied to be broken, symbolizing the defeat of Babylon’s gods.
An everlasting agreement between God and His people, emphasizing faithfulness and restoration.
A metaphor describing the people’s urgent and humble departure from Babylon, like goats leading sheep.

outline.heading: Introduction and Call to Proclaim Babylon’s Fall
outline.description: God commands Jeremiah to declare Babylon’s impending capture and the confusion of its idols, while also promising the return and repentance of Israel and Judah.

outline.heading: Babylon’s Judgment Announced
outline.description: The chapter describes Israel as lost sheep and foretells the destruction of Babylon through a northern invasion, emphasizing the justice of God’s vengeance.

outline.heading: The Punishment of Babylon’s Pride and Power
outline.description: God declares He will punish Babylon’s king and land, dismantle its military strength, and bring desolation as a consequence of its arrogance and oppression.

outline.heading: The Redeemer and Restoration of Israel
outline.description: Despite Babylon’s destruction, God promises to restore Israel and Judah, highlighting His role as Redeemer and the eventual cleansing of their sins.

outline.heading: The Final Siege and Fall of Babylon
outline.description: A great northern army will come against Babylon, causing fear and defeat, fulfilling God’s sovereign plan to desolate the city and end its oppression.

application: Trust in God's sovereign justice: Even powerful nations and rulers are subject to God's judgment when they oppose Him and oppress His people.
Repentance leads to restoration: Like Israel and Judah, believers should seek God earnestly and commit to a perpetual covenant with Him.
Avoid pride and idolatry: Babylon’s downfall warns Christians to remain humble and reject anything that competes with God’s authority.
Stand firm in faith during trials: God’s promises of redemption encourage believers to endure hardship, knowing He will ultimately vindicate His people.

keyVerses.text: They shall ask the way to Zion with their faces thitherward, saying, Come, and let us join ourselves to the LORD in a perpetual covenant that shall not be forgotten.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the hopeful future restoration and renewed covenant relationship between God and His people.

keyVerses.text: Call together the archers against Babylon: all ye that bend the bow, camp against it round about; let none thereof escape: recompense her according to her work; according to all that she hath done, do unto her: for she hath been proud against the LORD, against the Holy One of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the certainty of Babylon’s judgment because of its pride and rebellion against God.

keyVerses.text: Their Redeemer is strong; the LORD of hosts is his name: he shall throughly plead their cause, that he may give rest to the land, and disquiet the inhabitants of Babylon.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God’s power as Redeemer who defends His people and brings justice upon their oppressors.

keyVerses.text: At the noise of the taking of Babylon the earth is moved, and the cry is heard among the nations.
keyVerses.significance: It portrays the global impact and significance of Babylon’s fall as a momentous event ordained by God.
